text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here the Internet's
busiest music nerd thank you for
watching
it's time for an album review machine
drums rooms machine drum is the solo
effort of electronic music producer
Travis Stewart the sky has recorded
under some other names in the past he
currently has some new stuff out in the
duo sepal cure and the machine drum
discography as far as that goes
goes all the way back to the early 2000s
with the album now you know but this guy
doesn't have the following you would
expect somebody would if they were
creating music for over ten years he
recently got a nice endorsement from
Hudson Mohawke but he's still not a big
name in this genre it maybe it has
something to do with him kind of being a
musical chameleon his early stuff was
influenced by a lot of hip hop
instrumental hip hop kind of glitching
it out experimenting with it an eidm
every release after that would kind of
switch lanes between being more hip-hop
influenced or being more IDM influenced
and it kind of came to him even
embracing that wonky hip-hop sound
coming out of LA from producers like
Flying Lotus this is on that album want
to 1/2 it sounded like he was embracing
dubstep a little bit on some of the
tracks from that LP but he went even
deeper into that wonky sound on the mini
LP he put out afterwards many phases on
the first half of it on the second half
he plays with a lot of house and 2-step
songs but now the sounds of future
garage and this new sparse take on
dubstep is hot and now he's kind of
doing something that could be compared
to joy Orbison burial DL Scooba like any
other record in this style there are a
lot of broken clunky complicated beats
that just click tap pop heavy bass
sounds rumbling away in the background
not the wubwubwub they're just a lot of
thick synthesized bass and there's a ton
of atmosphere around the synthesizers
the vocal samples but there is something
very different about machine drum on
this thing he isn't very bleak he isn't
very atmospheric like a lot of artists
chasing this style
he just saturates the mix with tons of
different sounds and textures and I
would say it like kind of works in
layers like a lot of electronic music
does you know one sound on top of
another sound like a lasagna or
something like that but this is like
more of a 3d experience with sounds
popping up all over the place it's like
a galaxy of different sounds with stars
popping up here here back there Arang
from your face which makes it kind of
dizzying to listen to on headphones it's
really obvious that this new string of
producers coming out of the UK is
influencing this guy but he really
produces these tracks to be thick and
cacophonous like a producer would who
was making a drum and bass track or a
jungle track in the 90s but sometimes
this dude's love of experimental hip hop
instrumentals does kind of come back to
haunt some of these tracks a little bit
like with the very fat clumsy heavy beat
that would totally fit in a brain feeder
on the track sacred frequency the song
universe actually even sounds like
something Flying Lotus would do sans the
auto-tune
vocal samples I do like the future
Garage sound that machine drum is is
emulating on some of these tracks but
once he starts breeding that style with
other things some real Frankenstein's
kind of pop out like G B ye where this
guy really goes trigger-happy with the
vocal samples and the auto-tune there's
no possible way to escape them it's like
really overkill it's like taking a
bazooka to go deer hunting still despite
what genre hopping this album does it
comes off pretty cohesive pretty solid
stylistically and that's mostly because
machine
drum make sure that the sounds that are
being used are always high-quality he
really lays into these vocal samples
keeps those consistent and every single
one of these tracks just keeps a really
constant groove my main issue is that
some of these tracks just function
simply on throwing as much sound out
there as possible without really placing
them in a really interesting way and at
first I was like yeah this is fun this
is colorful this is overwhelming I like
it but the more I visited this record
the more I kind of saw through the
clouds the parting clouds the more I
kind of sorted out the clutter the more
I realized the magic just kind of was
disappearing for me the title track is a
good example which you know I thought
was pretty good at first but now that I
have everything on it all kind of
separated and interpreted I'm just still
there are some standouts on here I think
it's a pretty solid release overall I
just wish it stuck more truly to these
dubstep and future Garage sounds that
made machine drum kind of turn in this
direction in the first place because to
me those are the best tracks on here I
think we should ask coucher Chesto what
he thinks if this is a dubstep they like
to hear some DEP run or Deb jump and
that's why I hate him what do you think
of this thing do you love it do you hate
it why and what do you think I should
review next anthony Fantana machine drum
rooms fret
